what.question: What is a "relationship plan"?
what.intro: A marketing relationship plan is a strategic document that structures your CRM and marketing automation initiatives to build lasting customer relationships.
what.programsDesc: Coordinated action sets targeting specific objectives: Welcome, Loyalty, Reactivation, Cart Abandonment, Referral — each aligned to a customer lifecycle stage.
what.scenariosDesc: Message sequences triggered by customer behavior: welcome emails, post-purchase follow-ups, win-back campaigns — orchestrating the entire customer journey.

how.question: How does it work?
how.intro: Two ways to get your relationship marketing plan:
how.quickDesc: Select your industry and instantly get a template plan with 4-6 proven marketing programs tailored to your sector.
how.personalizedDesc: Enter your company domain and our AI analyzes your business to generate a fully customized plan with specific recommendations.

trust.question: Can I trust this plan?
trust.intro: We believe in transparency. Here's exactly how these plans are created:
trust.frameworkDesc: The structure follows the Marketing Relationship Plan methodology developed by
trust.frameworkDesc2: , a French CRM & Marketing Automation consulting firm.
trust.aiDesc: Personalized plans are generated by an AI we've refined with dozens of real examples. Template plans are curated by our team.
trust.purposeDesc: These plans are starting points to inspire your strategy. They're not a substitute for professional consulting.
trust.disclaimerText: AI-generated content may contain inaccuracies or "hallucinations." Always validate recommendations against your business knowledge and goals before implementing.

sidebar.industryPlanDesc: Get a comprehensive relationship marketing plan based on best practices for your industry.
sidebar.customPlanDesc: Our AI analyzes your company and creates a fully personalized plan with specific recommendations for your brand.
sidebar.step1Desc: Pick your sector and price tier — we'll show relevant benchmarks.
sidebar.step2Desc: Enter your metrics and get personalized AI recommendations.
sidebar.readyDesc: Fill in your metrics in the grid, then click "Generate AI Analysis" at the bottom of the page.

cac.name: Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)
cac.description: Total marketing spend divided by new customers acquired.
cac.definition: Customer Acquisition Cost represents the total cost to acquire one new customer, including all marketing and sales expenses.
cac.importance: CAC directly impacts profitability and determines how fast you can scale. Rising CAC is often the first sign of market saturation or inefficient spend allocation.
cac.formula: Total Marketing & Sales Costs ÷ New Customers Acquired
bestPractices: Calculate CAC by channel and campaign type
Include often-forgotten costs (tools, agency fees, creative)
Compare CAC trends month-over-month
Correlate CAC changes with market conditions

cac_payback.name: CAC Payback Period
cac_payback.description: Months to recover customer acquisition cost.
cac_payback.definition: The number of months required to recover the cost of acquiring a customer through their subscription payments.
cac_payback.importance: Payback period directly impacts cash flow and capital needs. Shorter payback means faster reinvestment in growth.
bestPractices: Target under 12 months for efficient growth
Compare payback by segment and channel
Factor in expected expansion revenue
Balance payback with LTV for optimal investment

roas.name: Blended ROAS
roas.description: Total revenue divided by total marketing spend.
roas.definition: Return on Ad Spend measures the revenue generated for every euro invested in advertising campaigns.
roas.importance: ROAS helps evaluate campaign-level performance and guides budget allocation. However, it doesn't account for customer lifetime value or organic lift from brand awareness.
bestPractices: Set different ROAS targets by campaign objective (brand vs. performance)
Account for attribution windows and model limitations
Don't chase ROAS at the expense of scale
Compare platform-reported vs. actual tracked ROAS

marketing_spend.name: Marketing Spend % of Revenue
marketing_spend.description: Percentage of revenue allocated to marketing.
marketing_spend.definition: The percentage of total revenue allocated to marketing activities, including paid media, content, tools, and team costs.
marketing_spend.importance: This ratio helps benchmark your investment level against industry standards and indicates growth stage maturity. Early-stage companies typically spend more; mature ones optimize for efficiency.
bestPractices: Adjust targets based on growth objectives
Include all marketing costs, not just media
Track the mix between brand and performance spend
Plan for seasonal variations in spend ratio

ltv_cac.name: LTV:CAC Ratio
ltv_cac.description: Customer lifetime value divided by acquisition cost.
ltv_cac.definition: The LTV:CAC ratio compares the lifetime value of a customer (total revenue they generate over their relationship with you) to the cost of acquiring them.
ltv_cac.importance: This is arguably the most critical metric for sustainable growth. A ratio below 3:1 suggests you're spending too much to acquire customers who don't generate enough value. Above 5:1 might indicate you're under-investing in growth.
bestPractices: Track cohort-based LTV, not just averages
Include all acquisition costs (ads, content, sales)
Segment by channel to identify best-performing sources
Consider payback period alongside ratio

mer.name: Marketing Efficiency Ratio (MER)
mer.description: Total revenue divided by total marketing spend.
mer.definition: Marketing Efficiency Ratio measures total revenue generated per euro spent on marketing, including both paid and organic channels.
mer.importance: Unlike ROAS which focuses on specific campaigns, MER gives you the full picture of marketing efficiency. It helps identify when organic channels are compensating for underperforming paid ones.
bestPractices: Track MER alongside individual channel ROAS
Set MER targets based on your gross margin
Watch for MER declines as you scale (normal but must be managed)
Use MER to validate blended strategy effectiveness

conv_rate.name: Conversion Rate
conv_rate.description: Percentage of visitors who complete a purchase.
conv_rate.definition: The percentage of desktop website visitors who complete a purchase during their session.
conv_rate.importance: Conversion rate is your efficiency multiplier - even small improvements create significant revenue impact. Desktop typically converts higher than mobile due to easier comparison shopping.
bestPractices: Segment by traffic source (paid vs. organic converts differently)
A/B test checkout flow continuously
Monitor micro-conversions (add to cart, checkout start)
Don't optimize for CVR at the expense of traffic quality

conv_desktop.name: Desktop Conversion Rate
conv_desktop.definition: The percentage of desktop website visitors who complete a purchase during their session.
conv_desktop.importance: Desktop users typically show higher purchase intent and convert at 2-3x mobile rates. They're often in research mode with larger screens for comparison.
bestPractices: Optimize product pages for comparison shopping
Ensure fast page load times
Use clear CTAs and trust signals
Implement exit-intent strategies

mobile_conv.name: Mobile Conversion Rate
mobile_conv.definition: The percentage of mobile website visitors who complete a purchase during their session.
mobile_conv.importance: With 60-70% of traffic now mobile, this metric increasingly determines overall performance. Mobile conversion is typically 30-50% lower than desktop but improving rapidly.
bestPractices: Optimize for thumb-friendly navigation
Implement mobile payment options (Apple Pay, Google Pay)
Reduce form fields and use autofill
Test page speed - every second costs conversions

cart_abandon.name: Cart Abandonment Rate
cart_abandon.description: Percentage of carts abandoned before checkout.
cart_abandon.definition: The percentage of shopping carts that are created but not converted into purchases.
cart_abandon.importance: Cart abandonment represents your biggest conversion opportunity - these visitors showed clear purchase intent. Industry average is 70-80%, but even small reductions drive significant revenue.
bestPractices: Implement abandoned cart email sequences (ideally 3-part)
Be transparent about shipping costs early
Offer guest checkout
Test exit-intent offers carefully

aov.name: Average Order Value (AOV)
aov.definition: Average Order Value is the mean revenue per transaction across all orders.
aov.importance: AOV directly impacts profitability - higher AOV often means better unit economics. It's usually easier to increase AOV from existing customers than to acquire new ones.
bestPractices: Use strategic free shipping thresholds
Implement product bundles and kits
Show 'frequently bought together' recommendations
Test upsells at checkout (carefully)

email_rev_share.name: Email Revenue Share
email_rev_share.description: Percentage of revenue from email marketing.
email_rev_share.definition: The percentage of total revenue attributed to email marketing campaigns and automations.
email_rev_share.importance: Email is typically your highest-ROI channel with near-zero marginal cost. Strong email revenue share indicates healthy owned audience engagement and reduced dependency on paid acquisition.
bestPractices: Balance promotional vs. value-add content
Segment lists for relevance
Automate lifecycle emails (welcome, post-purchase, win-back)
Monitor deliverability and engagement metrics

sms_rev_share.name: SMS Revenue Share
sms_rev_share.description: Percentage of revenue from SMS marketing.
sms_rev_share.definition: The percentage of total revenue attributed to SMS marketing campaigns.
sms_rev_share.importance: SMS has 98% open rates vs. 20% for email. It's ideal for time-sensitive offers and high-intent moments, but requires careful frequency management to avoid opt-outs.
bestPractices: Reserve SMS for high-value, time-sensitive messages
Keep messages short and action-oriented
Respect frequency (1-4 messages/month max)
Use for transactional updates and flash sales

social_rev_share.name: Social Media Revenue Share
social_rev_share.description: Percentage of revenue from social media channels.
social_rev_share.definition: The percentage of total revenue attributed to social media marketing (organic posts, social commerce, influencer partnerships).
social_rev_share.importance: Social media drives discovery and brand awareness, especially for younger demographics. It's increasingly becoming a direct sales channel with social commerce features.
bestPractices: Focus on platforms where your audience is most active
Invest in shoppable content and social commerce
Balance organic content with paid social advertising
Leverage user-generated content and reviews

paid_rev_share.name: Paid Advertising Revenue Share
paid_rev_share.description: Percentage of revenue from paid advertising.
paid_rev_share.definition: The percentage of total revenue attributed to paid advertising channels (search ads, display ads, social ads, retargeting).
paid_rev_share.importance: Paid advertising provides predictable, scalable growth but requires careful ROAS monitoring. Over-reliance on paid can erode margins.
bestPractices: Diversify across multiple paid channels
Implement proper attribution tracking
Balance paid acquisition with owned channel development
Regularly optimize campaigns based on ROAS data

organic_rev_share.name: Organic Search Revenue Share
organic_rev_share.description: Percentage of revenue from organic search (SEO).
organic_rev_share.definition: The percentage of total revenue attributed to organic search traffic (non-paid search engine results).
organic_rev_share.importance: Organic search provides sustainable, high-intent traffic with no media cost. Strong SEO reduces CAC and builds long-term competitive advantage.
bestPractices: Invest in content marketing and technical SEO
Optimize product pages for search intent
Build quality backlinks through PR and partnerships
Monitor and improve Core Web Vitals scores

repeat_rate.name: Repeat Purchase Rate
repeat_rate.description: Percentage of customers who make more than one purchase.
repeat_rate.definition: The percentage of customers who make more than one purchase within a defined period (typically 12 months).
repeat_rate.importance: Repeat customers are 5-25x cheaper to convert than new ones and typically have higher AOV. This metric is the foundation of sustainable, profitable growth.
bestPractices: Implement a post-purchase email sequence
Create loyalty or rewards programs
Personalize recommendations based on purchase history
Track time-to-second-purchase to optimize timing

purchase_freq.name: Purchase Frequency
purchase_freq.description: Average number of purchases per customer per year.
purchase_freq.definition: The average number of orders placed per customer over a 12-month period.
purchase_freq.importance: Frequency directly multiplies LTV. Understanding your natural purchase cycle helps time marketing touchpoints and identify at-risk customers before they churn.
bestPractices: Map your product's natural replenishment cycle
Implement subscription or auto-replenishment options
Create new purchase occasions (gifts, seasonal)
Trigger re-engagement at optimal intervals

churn_rate.name: Churn Rate
churn_rate.description: Percentage of customers who stop buying.
churn_rate.definition: The percentage of customers who do not make a repeat purchase within 12 months of their last order.
churn_rate.importance: Churn is the silent killer of growth - you might be acquiring customers fast while losing them faster. Reducing churn often has higher ROI than increasing acquisition.
churn_rate.formula: Customers Not Returning in 12 Months ÷ Total Active Customers × 100
bestPractices: Identify at-risk customers before they churn (RFM analysis)
Implement win-back campaigns
Survey churned customers to understand why
Calculate cost of churn vs. cost of retention

ltv.name: Customer Lifetime Value (LTV)
ltv.description: Total revenue expected from a customer over their lifetime.
ltv.definition: The total revenue a customer generates throughout their entire relationship with your business.
ltv.importance: LTV determines how much you can invest in acquisition and retention. It's the ultimate measure of customer relationship quality.
bestPractices: Calculate LTV by cohort and acquisition channel
Track leading indicators (engagement, NPS)
Focus on increasing frequency and reducing churn
Compare LTV to CAC for sustainable growth

return_rate.name: Return Rate
return_rate.definition: The percentage of sold items that are returned by customers.
return_rate.importance: Returns directly eat into margin and create operational costs. High returns often signal sizing/fit issues, poor product descriptions, or quality problems.
bestPractices: Improve product descriptions and sizing guides
Add more product photos and videos
Analyze return reasons by category
Consider virtual try-on or AR tools

gross_margin.name: Gross Margin
gross_margin.description: Revenue minus cost of goods sold, as percentage.
gross_margin.definition: The percentage of revenue remaining after subtracting the direct cost of goods sold (COGS).
gross_margin.importance: Gross margin sets the ceiling for all other spending - marketing, operations, profit. Low margin businesses need higher volume and efficiency to survive.
bestPractices: Negotiate with suppliers as you scale
Analyze margin by product category
Consider private label for margin improvement
Don't sacrifice margin for revenue growth

lead_conv.name: Lead-to-Customer Rate
lead_conv.description: Percentage of leads that become customers.
lead_conv.definition: The percentage of qualified leads that convert to opportunities or customers.
lead_conv.importance: Lead conversion efficiency determines how much you can afford to pay for leads. Low conversion often indicates poor targeting or nurturing gaps.
bestPractices: Define clear SQL criteria with sales alignment
Implement lead scoring based on behavior
Create targeted nurture sequences
Analyze conversion by source and persona

sql_rate.name: SQL Conversion Rate
sql_rate.description: Percentage of MQLs that become Sales Qualified Leads.
sql_rate.definition: The percentage of marketing qualified leads that become sales qualified leads.
sql_rate.importance: SQL rate measures marketing-sales alignment and lead quality. Low rates create tension between teams and waste resources.
bestPractices: Align on MQL and SQL definitions with sales
Implement feedback loops from sales to marketing
Review and update qualification criteria quarterly
Track speed-to-follow-up on MQLs

sales_cycle.name: Sales Cycle Length
sales_cycle.description: Average days from first contact to closed deal.
sales_cycle.definition: The average number of days from first contact to closed deal.
sales_cycle.importance: Cycle length impacts cash flow and forecast accuracy. Longer cycles require more nurturing investment but often yield larger deals.
sales_cycle.formula: Sum of Days to Close ÷ Number of Deals
bestPractices: Map your buyer's journey to identify bottlenecks
Create content for each decision stage
Implement lead scoring to prioritize ready buyers
Track cycle by deal size (larger deals naturally take longer)

nrr.name: Net Revenue Retention (NRR)
nrr.description: Revenue retained from existing customers including expansion.
nrr.definition: Net Revenue Retention measures revenue from existing customers including expansion, contraction, and churn.
nrr.importance: NRR above 100% means you grow even without new customers. It's the strongest indicator of product-market fit and customer satisfaction.
nrr.formula: (Start MRR + Expansion - Contraction - Churn) ÷ Start MRR × 100
bestPractices: Track expansion revenue (upsells, cross-sells)
Monitor early warning signs of contraction
Invest in customer success proactively
Identify expansion triggers and replicate them

expansion_revenue.name: Expansion Revenue
expansion_revenue.description: Revenue from upsells and cross-sells to existing customers.
expansion_revenue.definition: Additional revenue generated from existing customers through upsells, cross-sells, or plan upgrades.
expansion_revenue.importance: Expansion revenue is the most efficient growth lever - no acquisition cost required. High expansion indicates strong product-market fit.
bestPractices: Identify expansion-ready accounts proactively
Create clear upgrade paths in your product
Train customer success on expansion conversations
Monitor usage patterns that predict expansion

arr_growth.name: ARR Growth Rate
arr_growth.definition: The year-over-year percentage change in Annual Recurring Revenue.
arr_growth.importance: ARR growth rate is the primary valuation driver for SaaS companies. It indicates market traction and future potential.
arr_growth.formula: (Current ARR - Previous Year ARR) ÷ Previous Year ARR × 100
bestPractices: Track new vs. expansion vs. churned ARR separately
Monitor growth efficiency (ARR per sales rep)
Compare to Rule of 40 benchmark
Forecast based on pipeline and conversion rates

email_open_rate.name: Email Open Rate
email_open_rate.description: Percentage of delivered emails that are opened.
email_open_rate.definition: The percentage of delivered emails that recipients open. This is the first engagement indicator for your email campaigns.
email_open_rate.importance: Open rate is your first filter for email effectiveness. Low opens suggest subject line issues, poor sender reputation, or list quality problems. However, note that Apple Mail Privacy Protection can inflate open rates.
bestPractices: A/B test subject lines systematically
Optimize send times based on your audience
Keep sender name consistent and recognizable
Maintain clean lists to protect sender reputation

email_click_rate.name: Email Click Rate
email_click_rate.description: Percentage of delivered emails that receive a click.
email_click_rate.definition: The percentage of delivered emails where at least one link was clicked. Also called Click-Through Rate (CTR).
email_click_rate.importance: Click rate measures actual engagement with your email content. It shows whether your message and offers resonate with subscribers and drive them to take action.
bestPractices: Use clear, action-oriented CTAs
Place primary CTA above the fold
Personalize content based on segments
Ensure mobile-responsive design

email_ctor.name: Click-to-Open Rate (CTOR)
email_ctor.description: Percentage of opened emails that receive a click.
email_ctor.definition: Click-to-Open Rate measures the percentage of people who clicked after opening the email. It isolates content effectiveness from deliverability.
email_ctor.importance: CTOR is the purest measure of email content quality. A high open rate with low CTOR means your subject line works but content disappoints. This helps diagnose where to focus optimization.
bestPractices: Align content with subject line promise
Use compelling visuals and scannable layouts
Test different content formats and lengths
Create urgency or exclusivity when appropriate

email_unsub_rate.name: Unsubscribe Rate
email_unsub_rate.description: Percentage of recipients who unsubscribe per campaign.
email_unsub_rate.definition: The percentage of recipients who unsubscribe per email campaign. This is a key indicator of subscriber satisfaction and content relevance.
email_unsub_rate.importance: Unsubscribes signal content-audience mismatch or frequency fatigue. While some churn is natural, consistently high unsubscribe rates damage long-term list value and can indicate reputation problems.
bestPractices: Segment lists for relevance
Let subscribers manage frequency preferences
Deliver on the promise made at signup
Monitor unsubscribe reasons for patterns

email_bounce_rate.name: Bounce Rate
email_bounce_rate.description: Percentage of emails that fail to deliver.
email_bounce_rate.definition: The percentage of sent emails that fail to deliver. Includes hard bounces (permanent failures) and soft bounces (temporary issues).
email_bounce_rate.importance: High bounce rates damage sender reputation and can lead to blacklisting. Hard bounces above 2% are a red flag that requires immediate list cleaning. ISPs monitor this closely.
bestPractices: Use double opt-in for new subscribers
Remove hard bounces immediately
Re-engage or remove inactive subscribers
Validate email addresses at collection

email_deliverability.name: Deliverability Rate
email_deliverability.description: Percentage of emails successfully delivered to inbox.
email_deliverability.definition: The percentage of sent emails that successfully reach recipients' inboxes (not spam or promotions folders).
email_deliverability.importance: Deliverability is the foundation of email marketing ROI. Even perfect content fails if it doesn't reach the inbox. This metric reflects your overall email health and sender reputation.
email_deliverability.formula: Emails Delivered to Inbox ÷ Emails Sent × 100
bestPractices: Authenticate with SPF, DKIM, and DMARC
Maintain consistent sending volumes
Monitor blacklist status regularly
Warm up new IPs and domains gradually

analysis.comparingDataDesc: Examining thousands of data points from similar businesses.
analysis.findingOpportunitiesDesc: Finding the best growth levers for your business.
analysis.craftingRecsDesc: Almost there! Generating your personalized strategic insights.
analysis.resultSubtitle: Personalized insights based on your data

banner.instruction: Pick metrics - Set values - Generate insights

marketingPlan.pageSubtitle: Generate a customized marketing relationship plan for your business. Choose an industry template or get a personalized AI-powered plan.

marketingPlan.step2Desc: Browse the template plan or enter your domain for AI personalization
marketingPlan.step3Desc: Execute your plan using Brevo's omnichannel marketing platform
marketingPlan.sidebarDesc: Generate a customized marketing relationship plan for your business
marketingPlan.staticPlanDesc: Get a ready-to-use marketing plan template based on industry best practices. No email required.
marketingPlan.aiPoweredDesc: Our AI analyzes your company and creates a fully personalized marketing plan tailored to your business.
marketingPlan.ctaSectionTitle: Ready to Execute Your Marketing Plan?
marketingPlan.ctaSectionDesc: Brevo provides all the tools you need to implement your marketing relationship programs: Email, SMS, WhatsApp, Marketing Automation, and CRM.

marketingPlan.errorTip1: Use an established company domain with public presence
marketingPlan.errorTip2: Avoid generic domains like example.com or test.com
marketingPlan.errorTip3: Try companies with active marketing presence
